[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Priest](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priest "wikipedia:Priest")***

- *This article is about the role. For the monster, see [aligned priest](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest").*

**Priest** (**priestess** if female) is one of the [roles](/wiki/Role "Role") in NetHack, capable of playing any [alignment](/wiki/Alignment "Alignment") as a [human](/wiki/Human_\(starting_race\) "Human (starting race)"), or restricted to chaotic as an [elf](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)"). A priest's religion is chosen randomly from the [pantheons](/wiki/Pantheon "Pantheon") of the other roles. A human priest is therefore capable of representing any of the other roles' [gods](/wiki/God "God") in the game.

The [guidebook](/wiki/Guidebook "Guidebook") has this to say about Priests.

```
    Priests and Priestesses are clerics militant, crusaders advancing the cause of righteousness with arms, armor, and arts thaumaturgic. Their ability to commune with deities via prayer occasionally extricates them from peril, but can also put them in it.
```

## Starting equipment

Priests start with the following items:

- a [blessed](/wiki/Blessed "Blessed") +1 [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace")

- a +0 [robe](/wiki/Robe "Robe")

- a +0 [small shield](/wiki/Small_shield "Small shield") (like those of [aligned priests](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest"))

- 1–2 cloves of [garlic](/wiki/Garlic "Garlic")

- 1–2 [sprigs of wolfsbane](/wiki/Sprig_of_wolfsbane "Sprig of wolfsbane")

- 2 random [spellbooks](/wiki/Spellbook "Spellbook") of level 3 or lower (suitable for priests: [clerical](/wiki/Clerical "Clerical"), [divination](/wiki/Divination "Divination"), or [healing spells](/wiki/Healing_spells "Healing spells"))

- 4 potions of [holy water](/wiki/Holy_water "Holy water")

- a chance at one of the following:

  - a [magic marker](/wiki/Magic_marker "Magic marker") (10% chance)
  - an [oil lamp](/wiki/Oil_lamp "Oil lamp") (9% chance)

- If an elf, a random non-magical [instrument](/wiki/Instrument "Instrument").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

As of [commit 9d910773](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/9d910773d0a5421a259a228f638f87a04ef2d7a0), Priests have a 20% chance of starting with a magic marker and 8% chance of an oil lamp.

## Intrinsics

Priests gain the following [intrinsics](/wiki/Intrinsic "Intrinsic") at these [experience levels](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level"):[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

- Level 15: [Warning](/wiki/Warning "Warning")
- Level 20: [Fire resistance](/wiki/Fire_resistance "Fire resistance")

## Skills

| Priest skills |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |
| ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Max           | [Skills](/wiki/Skill "Skill")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |
| Basic         | - *Weapons:* [lance](/wiki/Lance "Lance"), [bow](/wiki/Bow "Bow"), [sling](/wiki/Sling "Sling"), [crossbow](/wiki/Crossbow "Crossbow"), [dart](/wiki/Dart "Dart"), [shuriken](/wiki/Shuriken "Shuriken"), [boomerang](/wiki/Boomerang "Boomerang")
- *Combat:* [bare hands](/wiki/Bare_hands "Bare hands")                                                                                                          |
| Skilled       | * *Weapons:* [polearms](/wiki/Polearms "Polearms"), [spear](/wiki/Spear "Spear"), [trident](/wiki/Trident "Trident"), [unicorn horn](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |
| Expert        | - *Weapons:* [club](/wiki/Club "Club"), [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace"), [morning star](/wiki/Morning_star "Morning star"), [flail](/wiki/Flail "Flail"), [hammer](/wiki/Hammer "Hammer"), [quarterstaff](/wiki/Quarterstaff "Quarterstaff")
- *Spells:* [healing](/wiki/Healing_spells "Healing spells"), [divination](/wiki/Divination_spells "Divination spells"), [clerical](/wiki/Clerical_spells "Clerical spells") |

Priests start with *Basic* skill in *Mace* and *Clerical spells*. The spellcasting skill is always *Clerical*, no matter what spellbooks a character starts with, because the initial spellcasting skills are hardcoded in the function *skill\_init* in [weapon.c](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/src/weapon.c "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/src/weapon.c") and are independent of the starting inventory. Their special spell is [remove curse](/wiki/Spell_of_remove_curse "Spell of remove curse").

## Special rules

Priests automatically know the [beatitude](/wiki/Beatitude "Beatitude") of all [items](/wiki/Item "Item"). This doesn't require sight or touch -- any item you're aware of, for any reason, will show its beatitude. If no [BUC](/wiki/BUC "BUC") is shown, that means the item is uncursed. (You can force the game to include the "uncursed" descriptor by setting `!implicit_uncursed` in your [options](/wiki/Options "Options").)

Priests don't receive the [multishot](/wiki/Multishot "Multishot") bonus for their [race](/wiki/Race "Race") or being Skilled at their weapon; thus, they can never fire more than one missile per move.

As the guidebook (somewhat obtusely) alludes to, Priests can also #[turn undead](/wiki/Turn_undead "Turn undead").

## Strategy

### Character creation

Priests are restricted in most edged weapons, including many desirable weapon skills, and players may elect to work around this by means of a [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift"). For such players, lawful priests have the best chance of receiving a viable [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") in the form of an artifact [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword") such as [Sunsword](/wiki/Sunsword "Sunsword") or even [Grayswandir](/wiki/Grayswandir "Grayswandir"), with the unrestricted skill making [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur") an option as well. Neutral priests have somewhat less reliable options for a first gift, though they may receive [Mjollnir](/wiki/Mjollnir "Mjollnir"), which is a quite powerful artifact in its own right and can be advanced to Expert skill. While most chaotic options for first sacrifice gift options are somewhat useless, elven Priests can force [Stormbringer](/wiki/Stormbringer "Stormbringer") by naming [Sting](/wiki/Sting "Sting") and [Orcrist](/wiki/Orcrist "Orcrist") beforehand.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

[Demonbane](/wiki/Demonbane "Demonbane") is now a mace and is the first sacrifice gift for Priests of any alignment, so lawful Priests can no longer deterministically unrestrict long sword skill, nor can elves force Stormbringer. Lawful Priests are still likely to get a long sword as their second gift.

For those not planning to use an artifact weapon, priests in general can be quite fragile in the early game unless they elect to wear armor. Lawful priests have the least perilous trip through the [Mines](/wiki/Mines "Mines") early on, while chaotic priests gain more "immediate" benefits from [sacrifice](/wiki/Sacrifice "Sacrifice") due to prayer timeout reduction, which can aid in farming [spellbooks](/wiki/Spellbook "Spellbook"); chaotic priests will also have an easier time dealing with the [mysterious force](/wiki/Mysterious_force "Mysterious force").

Elven Priests tend to be the most fragile of all available choices, and need assistance from equipment to reach the maximum [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") damage bonus or even maximum [carrying capacity](/wiki/Encumbrance "Encumbrance"). Their higher maximum [attributes](/wiki/Attribute "Attribute") for casting stats may not make as much difference in [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting") success by the time you can actually reach those limits, although the [energy](/wiki/Energy "Energy") growth bonus is somewhat helpful.

### Early game

#### Weapons

One disadvantage of the Priest is their weapon skill set. Priests can't gain [skill](/wiki/Skill#Weapon_skills "Skill") in any edged weapons, and can't [multishot](/wiki/Multishot#Eligible_missiles "Multishot") any ranged weapons. Combined with no skill in the [attack spells](/wiki/Spellbook#Attack "Spellbook"), this makes it hard for priests to find a good way to kill monsters.

Instead, a Priest's best ranged option early game is the [aklys](/wiki/Aklys "Aklys"), which they can pick up in the mines and can advance to up to Expert. Skill and enchantment investments on the aklys can be useful for the entire game.

The starting +1 [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace") is slightly better than a +0 long sword at Basic skill against small monsters. It is much less effective against large monsters, but these typically appear later. Priests that can find a [unicorn horn](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn") and train the skill may find it a sufficient weapon that lasts them until the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle"), especially if they elect to enchant it. Like any character, a Priest will want to sacrifice for an artifact weapon as soon as possible. Lawful priests should generally dip for [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur") as soon as they can survive any fountain spawns. Even unskilled, Excalibur is better than other available options.

#### Armor

Metallic armor and [shields](/wiki/Shield "Shield") are worth wearing to get your AC down; your starting spells don't generally need to be cast quickly, so when you do need to cast them you can find a quiet spot and disrobe. You will want to switch to non-metallic armor with a good AC as it becomes available.

#### Spellcasting

A priest starts with a [robe](/wiki/Robe "Robe") which aids spellcasting, and can use their potions of holy water to bless spellbooks they find, thus gaining more spells. However, they may have better uses for holy water.

A priest should focus on melee combat because most of their starting spells aren't useful in a fight. However, they are very capable of casting low-level spells such as [sleep](/wiki/Spellbook_of_sleep "Spellbook of sleep") and [force bolt](/wiki/Spellbook_of_force_bolt "Spellbook of force bolt").

The most useful combat spells that a priest can start with are [protection](/wiki/Spellbook_of_protection "Spellbook of protection") and [healing](/wiki/Spellbook_of_healing "Spellbook of healing"). Utility spells, especially [identify](/wiki/Spellbook_of_identify "Spellbook of identify"), can also give a priest a significant advantage once they are able to cast them.

#### General

Priests' ability to tell the beatitude of items and their starting holy water gives them advantages in the early game:

- They can identify which weapons, armor, and rings are safe to equip even if they have lost their pet. Another character who cannot [pet-test](/wiki/Curse-testing "Curse-testing") must drag everything to an altar.
- They can more easily get the more useful blessed effects of scrolls such as identify, genocide, enchant armor, and enchant weapon.
- They can remove curses with holy water or by blessing [scrolls of remove curse](/wiki/Scroll_of_remove_curse "Scroll of remove curse").
- They can get an early wish if they find a [magic lamp](/wiki/Magic_lamp "Magic lamp"); they may wish to go to [Mine Town](/wiki/Mine_Town "Mine Town") early to see if there is one to buy.
- Priests can easily uncurse items they find in [bones files](/wiki/Bones_file "Bones file").

Consider stashing at least one of your starting potions of holy water as early as possible, to keep from losing it to cold/fire/lightning attacks. As long as you have one potion, you can make more at will.

If you manage to get an early wish, dragon scale mail is generally more useful than a weapon, because AC and non-metallic body armor are useful things for a priest to have.

You should [#turn](/wiki/Turn_undead "Turn undead") undead only if you are certain that there are no non-[undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") monsters nearby.

##### Atheist conduct

Priests are well suited to the [atheist](/wiki/Atheist "Atheist") conduct, because they need not use altars to ascertain beatitude.

Lycanthropy can be dealt with using your starting wolfsbane. Removing curses is easy with the starting holy water.

Using #turn will break atheist conduct, as will using #chat on a priest (monster).

### Mid game

#### Objectives

The quest has mostly weaker [zombies](/wiki/Zombie_\(monster_class\) "Zombie (monster class)") and only a few strong monsters, and the large number of graveyards contain many boxes full of items. There is more treasure on this quest than any other. [Drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance") or [MC](/wiki/MC "MC")3 is useful to prevent [level drain](/wiki/Drain_life_\(monster_attack\) "Drain life (monster attack)") from [wraiths](/wiki/Wraith_\(monster_class\) "Wraith (monster class)") and [vampires](/wiki/Vampire_\(monster_class\) "Vampire (monster class)"). If you are not at a high enough level for the Quest but have access to [create monster](/wiki/Create_monster "Create monster") in some form, you can gain levels by creating wraiths on the home level and luring them back through the portal.

The unaligned altar can be converted and used for sacrificing, but monster generation is low and most generated monsters are undead that cannot be sacrificed; you can obtain useful corpses by [kicking](/wiki/Kicking "Kicking") the [trees](/wiki/Tree "Tree") on the home level to summon [killer bees](/wiki/Killer_bee "Killer bee"), then lure them closer to the altar.

Some priests that get to the Castle will be strong enough to face the monsters in direct combat, or use the [passtune](/wiki/Passtune "Passtune") to crush more difficult monsters with the drawbridge.

#### Spellcasting

Except for attack spells, Priests are decent spell-casters. They can advance to expert in clerical, divination and healing, but are restricted in other classes. Note that their spellcasting prowess is based on Wisdom, not Intelligence (but the odds of learning a new spell still depend on Intelligence). Even with attack spells restricted, the simpler ones (i.e., level 3 and below) may still be of use.

Skill slots are not in short supply; a Priest has few weapon skills, and may gain many levels from wraith corpses in the [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest"). Advancing divinations to Skilled enhances the effects of spells like [detect monsters](/wiki/Spellbook_of_detect_monsters "Spellbook of detect monsters"), [detect treasure](/wiki/Spellbook_of_detect_treasure "Spellbook of detect treasure"), and identify, but advancing the school to Expert only improves spell failure rates.

### Late game

#### Spellcasting

A high level priest may be able to make use of a [spellbook of polymorph](/wiki/Spellbook_of_polymorph "Spellbook of polymorph"), despite having no skill in matter spells, by using the [Mitre of Holiness](/wiki/Mitre_of_Holiness "Mitre of Holiness") and a robe.

At skilled divination, Priests should be able to cast [magic mapping](/wiki/Spellbook_of_magic_mapping "Spellbook of magic mapping"), which should make [Gehennom mapping](/wiki/Gehennom_mapping "Gehennom mapping") a trivial task.

You can learn simple attack spells (like [force bolt](/wiki/Force_bolt "Force bolt") or [drain life](/wiki/Spellbook_of_drain_life "Spellbook of drain life")) and cast them with 0% failure rate. [Magic missile](/wiki/Magic_missile "Magic missile") is especially useful at high levels, as its damage scales up with your level - which can easily be increased due to the wraiths in the quest.

## Rank titles

The [status line](/wiki/Status_line "Status line") shows you to be one of the following ranks when you reach the specified experience level:

- XL 1–2: Aspirant
- XL 3–5: Acolyte
- XL 6–9: Adept
- XL 10–13: Priest/Priestess
- XL 14–17: Curate
- XL 18–21: Canon/Canoness
- XL 22–25: Lama
- XL 26–29: Patriarch/Matriarch
- XL 30: High Priest/High Priestess

## Quest

- *Main article: [Priest quest](/wiki/Priest_quest "Priest quest")*

[Nalzok](/wiki/Nalzok "Nalzok"), the Priest [quest nemesis](/wiki/Quest_nemesis "Quest nemesis"), is quite tough, but he respects [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth") and the [scroll of scare monster](/wiki/Scroll_of_scare_monster "Scroll of scare monster"). The quest is rather boring, but extremely profitable. All the levels contain several graveyards with [wraiths](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith") and chests full of goodies. The locate level may also contain several sleeping [foocubi](/wiki/Foocubi "Foocubi"), which you should not disturb until you are able to utilize them without the risk of negative effects. Given all the graveyards and sleeping monsters, some source of [stealth](/wiki/Stealth "Stealth") is advisable before attempting this quest.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

The scroll of scare monster on the ground no longer scares any [unique](/wiki/Unique "Unique") monster.

The quest artifact is [The Mitre of Holiness](/wiki/The_Mitre_of_Holiness "The Mitre of Holiness"), which has a great base item in the [helm of brilliance](/wiki/Helm_of_brilliance "Helm of brilliance"); the Mitre additionally allows you to #[invoke](/wiki/Invoke "Invoke") it to regain your [power](/wiki/Power "Power"), gives [fire resistance](/wiki/Fire_resistance "Fire resistance") and halves damage from the [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") and most [demons](/wiki/Demons "Demons"). However, unlike many quest artifacts, it doesn't confer [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance"), so you have to get that from a different source.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), Priests can be [doppelgangers](/wiki/Doppelganger "Doppelganger"), [drow](/wiki/Drow "Drow"), [elves](/wiki/Elf "Elf"), [hobbits](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit"), or [humans](/wiki/Human "Human").

#### Starting equipment

- blessed +0 [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace")
- blessed +0 [robe](/wiki/Robe "Robe") (note that in SLASH'EM, an ordinary robe does not enhance spellcasting; that requires a [robe of power](/wiki/Robe_of_power "Robe of power"))
- blessed +2 [small shield](/wiki/Small_shield "Small shield")
- 1–2 blessed [cloves of garlic](/wiki/Clove_of_garlic "Clove of garlic")
- 1–2 blessed [sprigs of wolfsbane](/wiki/Sprig_of_wolfsbane "Sprig of wolfsbane")
- [spellbook of healing](/wiki/Spellbook_of_healing "Spellbook of healing")
- spellbook of [force bolt](/wiki/Spellbook_of_force_bolt "Spellbook of force bolt"), [sleep](/wiki/Spellbook_of_sleep "Spellbook of sleep"), [resist poison](/wiki/Spellbook_of_resist_poison "Spellbook of resist poison"), [resist sleep](/wiki/Spellbook_of_resist_sleep "Spellbook of resist sleep"), [detect food](/wiki/Spellbook_of_detect_food "Spellbook of detect food"), [detect monsters](/wiki/Spellbook_of_detect_monsters "Spellbook of detect monsters"), [light](/wiki/Spellbook_of_light "Spellbook of light"), [knock](/wiki/Spellbook_of_knock "Spellbook of knock"), or [wizard lock](/wiki/Spellbook_of_wizard_lock "Spellbook of wizard lock")
- random blessed [scroll](/wiki/Scroll "Scroll")
- 4 potions of [holy water](/wiki/Holy_water "Holy water")
- 10% chance of [magic marker](/wiki/Magic_marker "Magic marker"), otherwise 10% chance of light source (50% chance of [oil lamp](/wiki/Oil_lamp "Oil lamp"), 50% chance of [torches](/wiki/Torch "Torch"))

#### Skills

Priest spell skills are different than in vanilla. Also of note, they can become skilled in [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword").

| Priest skills |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |
| ------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Max           | Skills                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |
| Basic         | - *Weapons:* [lance](/wiki/Lance "Lance"), [bow](/wiki/Bow "Bow"), [sling](/wiki/Sling "Sling"), [crossbow](/wiki/Crossbow "Crossbow"), [dart](/wiki/Dart "Dart"), [shuriken](/wiki/Shuriken "Shuriken"), [boomerang](/wiki/Boomerang "Boomerang")
- *Combat:* [bare hands](/wiki/Bare_hands "Bare hands")
- *Spells:* [attack](/wiki/Attack_spells "Attack spells"), [enchantment](/wiki/Enchantment_spells "Enchantment spells"), [body](/wiki/Body_spells "Body spells"), [matter](/wiki/Matter_spells "Matter spells") |
| Skilled       | * *Weapons:* [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword"), [polearms](/wiki/Polearms "Polearms"), [spear](/wiki/Spear "Spear"), [javelin](/wiki/Javelin "Javelin"), [trident](/wiki/Trident "Trident"), [unicorn horn](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn")
* *Spells:* [protection](/wiki/Protection_spells "Protection spells")                                                                                                                                                                                             |
| Expert        | - *Weapons:* [club](/wiki/Club "Club"), [paddle](/wiki/Paddle "Paddle"), [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace"), [morning star](/wiki/Morning_star "Morning star"), [flail](/wiki/Flail "Flail"), [hammer](/wiki/Hammer "Hammer"), [quarterstaff](/wiki/Quarterstaff "Quarterstaff")
- *Spells:* [healing](/wiki/Healing_spells "Healing spells"), [divination](/wiki/Divination_spells "Divination spells")                                                                                                                            |

#### Techniques

|           |                                                                 |
| --------- | --------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Level** | **Technique**                                                   |
| 1         | [Turn undead](/wiki/Turn_undead "Turn undead")                  |
| 1         | [Blessing](/wiki/Blessing_\(technique\) "Blessing (technique)") |

#### Strategy

In SLASH'EM, Priests get [Disrupter](/wiki/Disrupter "Disrupter") as their first sacrifice gift, which is very useful in their quest as it grants +5 to hit and +30 to damage against the undead. It is not terribly useful as a main weapon, but makes a good secondary weapon to use against [liches](/wiki/Lich "Lich") and [vampire mages](/wiki/Vampire_mage_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Vampire mage (SLASH'EM)"). Make sure to enchant it to be able to hit undead with enchantment resistance!

Lawful Priests can try to use [Skullcrusher](/wiki/Skullcrusher "Skullcrusher"), which can be gotten by sacrifice. If you are good at unmounted polearm tactics, then [Reaper](/wiki/Reaper "Reaper") can be another option. The previously-good wish, [the Sceptre of Might](/wiki/The_Sceptre_of_Might "The Sceptre of Might"), is a much weaker weapon in SLASH'EM; it now does a flat +3 to hit and +5 to damage against cross-aligned, instead of double damage.

Neutral Priests do not get any new options and should go for [Mjollnir](/wiki/Mjollnir "Mjollnir") (now a heavy hammer) or [the Staff of Aesculapius](/wiki/The_Staff_of_Aesculapius "The Staff of Aesculapius").

Chaotic Priests can use the [Bat from Hell](/wiki/Bat_from_Hell "Bat from Hell"), which can by gotten by sacrifice. They can also use [Plague](/wiki/Plague "Plague") or [Hellfire](/wiki/Hellfire "Hellfire") for ranged combat; both may be obtained through sacrifice. Arrows shot from Plague are automatically poisoned, and bolts shot from Hellfire explode and deal fire damage.

### FIQHack

[FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack") priests can be [orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)").

Priests get a +20 bonus to effective XL when writing scrolls. Thus at XL30 they can always write unknown scrolls.

[Turning undead](/wiki/Turn_undead "Turn undead") has been buffed compared to vanilla.

## Encyclopedia entry

For the two priests were talking exactly like priests, piously, with learning and leisure, about the most aerial enigmas of theology. The little Essex priest spoke the more simply, with his round face turned to the strengthening stars; the other talked with his head bowed, as if he were not even worthy to look at them. But no more innocently clerical conversation could have been heard in any white Italian cloister or black Spanish cathedral. The first he heard was the tail of one of Father Brown's sentences, which ended: "... what they really meant in the Middle Ages by the heavens being incorruptible." The taller priest nodded his bowed head and said: "Ah, yes, these modern infidels appeal to their reason; but who can look at those millions of worlds and not feel that there may well be wonderful universes above us where reason is utterly unreasonable?"

\[ The Innocence of Father Brown, by G.K. Chesterton ]

Wikipedia has an article about:
Priest
This article is about the role. For the monster, see aligned priest.

Priest (priestess if female) is one of the roles in NetHack, capable of playing any alignment as a human, or restricted to chaotic as an elf. A priest's religion is chosen randomly from the pantheons of the other roles. A human priest is therefore capable of representing any of the other roles' gods in the game.

The guidebook has this to say about Priests. 

    Priests and Priestesses are clerics militant, crusaders advancing the cause of righteousness with arms, armor, and arts thaumaturgic. Their ability to commune with deities via prayer occasionally extricates them from peril, but can also put them in it.

Starting equipment

Priests start with the following items:

  • a blessed +1 mace
  • a +0 robe
  • a +0 small shield (like those of aligned priests)
  • 1–2 cloves of garlic
  • 1–2 sprigs of wolfsbane
  • 2 random spellbooks of level 3 or lower (suitable for priests: clerical, divination, or healing spells)
  • 4 potions of holy water
  • a chance at one of the following:
    • a magic marker (10% chance)
    • an oil lamp (9% chance)
  • If an elf, a random non-magical instrument.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

As of commit 9d910773, Priests have a 20% chance of starting with a magic marker and 8% chance of an oil lamp.

Intrinsics

Priests gain the following intrinsics at these experience levels:[1]

  • Level 15: Warning
  • Level 20: Fire resistance

Skills

Priest skills
Max Skills
Basic
  • Weapons: lance, bow, sling, crossbow, dart, shuriken, boomerang
  • Combat: bare hands
Skilled
  • Weapons: polearms, spear, trident, unicorn horn
Expert
  • Weapons: club, mace, morning star, flail, hammer, quarterstaff
  • Spells: healing, divination, clerical

Priests start with Basic skill in Mace and Clerical spells. The spellcasting skill is always Clerical, no matter what spellbooks a character starts with, because the initial spellcasting skills are hardcoded in the function skill_init in weapon.c and are independent of the starting inventory. Their special spell is remove curse.

Special rules

Priests automatically know the beatitude of all items. This doesn't require sight or touch -- any item you're aware of, for any reason, will show its beatitude. If no BUC is shown, that means the item is uncursed. (You can force the game to include the "uncursed" descriptor by setting !implicit_uncursed in your options.)

Priests don't receive the multishot bonus for their race or being Skilled at their weapon; thus, they can never fire more than one missile per move.

As the guidebook (somewhat obtusely) alludes to, Priests can also #turn undead.

Strategy

Character creation

Priests are restricted in most edged weapons, including many desirable weapon skills, and players may elect to work around this by means of a sacrifice gift. For such players, lawful priests have the best chance of receiving a viable artifact weapon in the form of an artifact long sword such as Sunsword or even Grayswandir, with the unrestricted skill making Excalibur an option as well. Neutral priests have somewhat less reliable options for a first gift, though they may receive Mjollnir, which is a quite powerful artifact in its own right and can be advanced to Expert skill. While most chaotic options for first sacrifice gift options are somewhat useless, elven Priests can force Stormbringer by naming Sting and Orcrist beforehand.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Demonbane is now a mace and is the first sacrifice gift for Priests of any alignment, so lawful Priests can no longer deterministically unrestrict long sword skill, nor can elves force Stormbringer. Lawful Priests are still likely to get a long sword as their second gift.

For those not planning to use an artifact weapon, priests in general can be quite fragile in the early game unless they elect to wear armor. Lawful priests have the least perilous trip through the Mines early on, while chaotic priests gain more "immediate" benefits from sacrifice due to prayer timeout reduction, which can aid in farming spellbooks; chaotic priests will also have an easier time dealing with the mysterious force.

Elven Priests tend to be the most fragile of all available choices, and need assistance from equipment to reach the maximum strength damage bonus or even maximum carrying capacity. Their higher maximum attributes for casting stats may not make as much difference in spellcasting success by the time you can actually reach those limits, although the energy growth bonus is somewhat helpful.

Early game

Weapons

One disadvantage of the Priest is their weapon skill set. Priests can't gain skill in any edged weapons, and can't multishot any ranged weapons. Combined with no skill in the attack spells, this makes it hard for priests to find a good way to kill monsters.

Instead, a Priest's best ranged option early game is the aklys, which they can pick up in the mines and can advance to up to Expert. Skill and enchantment investments on the aklys can be useful for the entire game.

The starting +1 mace is slightly better than a +0 long sword at Basic skill against small monsters. It is much less effective against large monsters, but these typically appear later. Priests that can find a unicorn horn and train the skill may find it a sufficient weapon that lasts them until the Castle, especially if they elect to enchant it. Like any character, a Priest will want to sacrifice for an artifact weapon as soon as possible. Lawful priests should generally dip for Excalibur as soon as they can survive any fountain spawns. Even unskilled, Excalibur is better than other available options.

Armor

Metallic armor and shields are worth wearing to get your AC down; your starting spells don't generally need to be cast quickly, so when you do need to cast them you can find a quiet spot and disrobe. You will want to switch to non-metallic armor with a good AC as it becomes available.

Spellcasting

A priest starts with a robe which aids spellcasting, and can use their potions of holy water to bless spellbooks they find, thus gaining more spells. However, they may have better uses for holy water.

A priest should focus on melee combat because most of their starting spells aren't useful in a fight. However, they are very capable of casting low-level spells such as sleep and force bolt.

The most useful combat spells that a priest can start with are protection and healing. Utility spells, especially identify, can also give a priest a significant advantage once they are able to cast them.

General

Priests' ability to tell the beatitude of items and their starting holy water gives them advantages in the early game:

  • They can identify which weapons, armor, and rings are safe to equip even if they have lost their pet. Another character who cannot pet-test must drag everything to an altar.
  • They can more easily get the more useful blessed effects of scrolls such as identify, genocide, enchant armor, and enchant weapon.
  • They can remove curses with holy water or by blessing scrolls of remove curse.
  • They can get an early wish if they find a magic lamp; they may wish to go to Mine Town early to see if there is one to buy.
  • Priests can easily uncurse items they find in bones files.

Consider stashing at least one of your starting potions of holy water as early as possible, to keep from losing it to cold/fire/lightning attacks. As long as you have one potion, you can make more at will.

If you manage to get an early wish, dragon scale mail is generally more useful than a weapon, because AC and non-metallic body armor are useful things for a priest to have.

You should #turn undead only if you are certain that there are no non-undead monsters nearby.

Atheist conduct

Priests are well suited to the atheist conduct, because they need not use altars to ascertain beatitude.

Lycanthropy can be dealt with using your starting wolfsbane. Removing curses is easy with the starting holy water.

Using #turn will break atheist conduct, as will using #chat on a priest (monster).

Mid game

Objectives

The quest has mostly weaker zombies and only a few strong monsters, and the large number of graveyards contain many boxes full of items. There is more treasure on this quest than any other. Drain resistance or MC3 is useful to prevent level drain from wraiths and vampires. If you are not at a high enough level for the Quest but have access to create monster in some form, you can gain levels by creating wraiths on the home level and luring them back through the portal.

The unaligned altar can be converted and used for sacrificing, but monster generation is low and most generated monsters are undead that cannot be sacrificed; you can obtain useful corpses by kicking the trees on the home level to summon killer bees, then lure them closer to the altar.

Some priests that get to the Castle will be strong enough to face the monsters in direct combat, or use the passtune to crush more difficult monsters with the drawbridge.

Spellcasting

Except for attack spells, Priests are decent spell-casters. They can advance to expert in clerical, divination and healing, but are restricted in other classes. Note that their spellcasting prowess is based on Wisdom, not Intelligence (but the odds of learning a new spell still depend on Intelligence). Even with attack spells restricted, the simpler ones (i.e., level 3 and below) may still be of use.

Skill slots are not in short supply; a Priest has few weapon skills, and may gain many levels from wraith corpses in the quest. Advancing divinations to Skilled enhances the effects of spells like detect monsters, detect treasure, and identify, but advancing the school to Expert only improves spell failure rates.

Late game

Spellcasting

A high level priest may be able to make use of a spellbook of polymorph, despite having no skill in matter spells, by using the Mitre of Holiness and a robe.

At skilled divination, Priests should be able to cast magic mapping, which should make Gehennom mapping a trivial task.

You can learn simple attack spells (like force bolt or drain life) and cast them with 0% failure rate. Magic missile is especially useful at high levels, as its damage scales up with your level - which can easily be increased due to the wraiths in the quest.

Rank titles

The status line shows you to be one of the following ranks when you reach the specified experience level:

  • XL 1–2: Aspirant
  • XL 3–5: Acolyte
  • XL 6–9: Adept
  • XL 10–13: Priest/Priestess
  • XL 14–17: Curate
  • XL 18–21: Canon/Canoness
  • XL 22–25: Lama
  • XL 26–29: Patriarch/Matriarch
  • XL 30: High Priest/High Priestess

Quest

Main article: Priest quest

Nalzok, the Priest quest nemesis, is quite tough, but he respects Elbereth and the scroll of scare monster. The quest is rather boring, but extremely profitable. All the levels contain several graveyards with wraiths and chests full of goodies. The locate level may also contain several sleeping foocubi, which you should not disturb until you are able to utilize them without the risk of negative effects. Given all the graveyards and sleeping monsters, some source of stealth is advisable before attempting this quest.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

The scroll of scare monster on the ground no longer scares any unique monster.

The quest artifact is The Mitre of Holiness, which has a great base item in the helm of brilliance; the Mitre additionally allows you to #invoke it to regain your power, gives fire resistance and halves damage from the undead and most demons. However, unlike many quest artifacts, it doesn't confer magic resistance, so you have to get that from a different source.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, Priests can be doppelgangers, drow, elves, hobbits, or humans.

Starting equipment

  • blessed +0 mace
  • blessed +0 robe (note that in SLASH'EM, an ordinary robe does not enhance spellcasting; that requires a robe of power)
  • blessed +2 small shield
  • 1–2 blessed cloves of garlic
  • 1–2 blessed sprigs of wolfsbane
  • spellbook of healing
  • spellbook of force bolt, sleep, resist poison, resist sleep, detect food, detect monsters, light, knock, or wizard lock
  • random blessed scroll
  • 4 potions of holy water
  • 10% chance of magic marker, otherwise 10% chance of light source (50% chance of oil lamp, 50% chance of torches)

Skills

Priest spell skills are different than in vanilla. Also of note, they can become skilled in long sword.

Priest skills
Max Skills
Basic
  • Weapons: lance, bow, sling, crossbow, dart, shuriken, boomerang
  • Combat: bare hands
  • Spells: attack, enchantment, body, matter
Skilled
  • Weapons: long sword, polearms, spear, javelin, trident, unicorn horn
  • Spells: protection
Expert
  • Weapons: club, paddle, mace, morning star, flail, hammer, quarterstaff
  • Spells: healing, divination

Techniques

Level Technique
1 Turn undead
1 Blessing


Strategy

In SLASH'EM, Priests get Disrupter as their first sacrifice gift, which is very useful in their quest as it grants +5 to hit and +30 to damage against the undead. It is not terribly useful as a main weapon, but makes a good secondary weapon to use against liches and vampire mages. Make sure to enchant it to be able to hit undead with enchantment resistance!

Lawful Priests can try to use Skullcrusher, which can be gotten by sacrifice. If you are good at unmounted polearm tactics, then Reaper can be another option. The previously-good wish, the Sceptre of Might, is a much weaker weapon in SLASH'EM; it now does a flat +3 to hit and +5 to damage against cross-aligned, instead of double damage.

Neutral Priests do not get any new options and should go for Mjollnir (now a heavy hammer) or the Staff of Aesculapius.

Chaotic Priests can use the Bat from Hell, which can by gotten by sacrifice. They can also use Plague or Hellfire for ranged combat; both may be obtained through sacrifice. Arrows shot from Plague are automatically poisoned, and bolts shot from Hellfire explode and deal fire damage.

FIQHack

FIQHack priests can be orcs.

Priests get a +20 bonus to effective XL when writing scrolls. Thus at XL30 they can always write unknown scrolls.

Turning undead has been buffed compared to vanilla.

Encyclopedia entry

For the two priests were talking exactly like priests, piously, with learning and leisure, about the most aerial enigmas of theology. The little Essex priest spoke the more simply, with his round face turned to the strengthening stars; the other talked with his head bowed, as if he were not even worthy to look at them. But no more innocently clerical conversation could have been heard in any white Italian cloister or black Spanish cathedral. The first he heard was the tail of one of Father Brown's sentences, which ended: "... what they really meant in the Middle Ages by the heavens being incorruptible." The taller priest nodded his bowed head and said: "Ah, yes, these modern infidels appeal to their reason; but who can look at those millions of worlds and not feel that there may well be wonderful universes above us where reason is utterly unreasonable?"

[ The Innocence of Father Brown, by G.K. Chesterton ]

If you are good at unmounted polearm tactics, then [[Reaper]] can be another option. The previously-good wish, [[the Sceptre of Might]], is a much weaker weapon in SLASH'EM; it now does a flat +3 to hit and +5 to damage against cross-aligned, instead of double damage. Neutral Priests do not get any new options and should go for [[Mjollnir]] (now a heavy hammer) or [[the Staff of Aesculapius]]. Chaotic Priests can use the [[Bat from Hell]], which can by gotten by sacrifice. They can also use [[Plague]] or [[Hellfire]] for ranged combat; both may be obtained through sacrifice. Arrows shot from Plague are automatically poisoned, and bolts shot from Hellfire explode and deal fire damage. ===FIQHack=== [[FIQHack]] priests can be [[Orc (starting race)|orcs]]. Priests get a +20 bonus to effective XL when writing scrolls. Thus at XL30 they can always write unknown scrolls.
